subject: Re: [junit] Testing philosophy question

messageBody:
On Nov 20, 2003, at 9:48 AM, Chappell, Simon P wrote:
>
> I'm helping some of our COBOL programmers learn Java in their own time
> and once a week I do a small lunchtime "chalk and talk" session.
> Lately, I have started introducing JUnit, on the grounds that the
> sooner I teach them good habits, the more likely they are to stick
> with them. I'm using the java.lang.String class as the object being
> tested, so that we only have to worry about writing one class instead
> of two.
>
> My question is: When testing overloaded methods (String.indexOf() in
> this specific case), is it better for each overloaded method get it's
> own testXXX() method or is it ok to lump them all in the one test? I
> have them all in one test right now, on the grounds that the test is
> against the index feature, rather than the individual methods.
>

When I'm writing learning tests of this sort, I usually group like
methods into a single test case method (e.g. testIndexing()). When I'm
writing production code, and I want to remember how to do string
indexing, the test contains examples of the all the indexing things I'm
able to do with a string.

If testIndexing() grows uncomfortably big, for example, then I'll break
it into individual test case methods. I know it's too big if I find
myself having to wade through too many examples to find the one example
I'm looking for. For example, I might end up with
testIndexingByCharacter and testIndexingByString. That effectively
cuts the example search in half, providing I know whether I'm working
with characters or strings.

But that's just what works for me.

Mike
